newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Russian precious metal plan does not include PGMs.
newsitem.headline: Russian precious metal plan does not include PGMs.

text.p: Russia's plans to liberalise precious metals exports do not apply to platinum group metals (PGMs), a Finance Ministry statement said on Thursday.

The statement, detailing plans adopted by Wednesday's conference on precious metals headed by First Deputy Prime Minister Anatoly Chubais, said the liberalisation of precious metals exports only applied to gold and silver.
"It is considered necessary...to hand to the government for signing plans of documents which look at...the liberalisation of precious metals exports (gold and silver)," the statement said.
It added that it hoped to have the documents agreed and signed by the government within two weeks.
The plan to liberalise gold exports would allow licensed commercial banks, as well as the central bank and government reserve Gokhran, to sell abroad, it said.
Another proposal made at the conference was to remove government regulation of precious metals prices in Russia.
"For the sake of taxation and accounting purposes, official price quotations for precious metals established by the central bank will be adopted," the statement said.
"But the government will continue to regulate the price of rough diamonds," it added.
The statement said that the plans were aimed at regulating economic relations between all branches of precious metals, including producers, refiners and users.
They would also increase liquidity in the gold market and boost the flow of money to the gold producing sector.
